_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES The Stearns Gas Plant has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Low Temperature Separation, Fractionation, Propane Storage, and Natural Gas Liquids Storage Systems. The Stearns Gas PlantA?s policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substance.

2. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE The gas plant is designed to convert sweet field gas into pipeline quality sales gas and natural gas liquids (natural gas liquids and propane). One LPG bullet has a working capacity of 24,000 gallons. The product storage tank has a working capacity of 48,000 gallons. 

3. HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary Scenario Description: Per the RMP Regulations, one worst-case flammable scenario has been defined for the Low Temperature Separation, Fractionation, Propane Storage, and Natural Gas Liquids Storage System. The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation. Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary Scenario Description: Per the RMP Regulations, one alternative-case flammable scenario has been defined for the Low Temperature Separation, Fractionation, Propane Storage, and Natural Gas Liquids Storage System.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation. 

4. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM As part of the implementation of RMP Program 3, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by the Stearns Gas Plant to manage process safety issues associated with flammables. Prevention Program 3 elements include: 

Prevention Program 3 Elements 
Process Safety Information (PSI) Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) Operating Procedures (OP) Training (TRN) Mechanical Integrity (MI) Management

of Change (MOC) Pre-Startup Review (PSSR) Compliance Audits (CA) Incident Investigation (II) Employee Participation (EP) Hot Work Permit (HWP) Contractors (CON) Emergency Response 

5. FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY There have been no RMP-applicable releases at the facility in at least the past five (5) years. 

6. EXTERNAL EVENTS ANALYSIS Pursuant to the requirements of California Health & Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, A?2745.7(q); the following external events analysis information shall be submitted: -The types of natural and human caused external events considered in PHA Section 2760.2 or Hazard Review Section 2755.2. --During the July 2006 PHA a broad list of external events was considered by the Team.  General events external to the plant that can conceivably cause a release were addressed.  The External Events that were considered credible include, but are not limited to, earthquake, external fire, and human error/misoperation. The facility also conducted a separate Seismic Assessment report that was submitted to LA County Fire Department. 

-The estimated magnitude or scope of external events which were considered
If not known, the owner or operator of the stationary source shall work closely with the AA to determine what is required. If seismic events are applicable, the parameters used in the consideration of the seismic analysis and which edition of the Uniform Building Code was used when the process was designed. --The magnitudes of the external events considered are detailed within the PHA Worksheets and were 
qualitatively risk-ranked by the PHA Team. 
-For each external event, with a potential to create a release of a regulated substance that will reach an endpoint offsite, apply 1) The expected date of completion of any changes resulting from the PHA; 2) Major hazards identified; 3) Process controls in use; 4) Mitigation systems in use; 5) Monitoring and detection systems in use; and, 6) Changes since the last Hazard Review (HR) or PHA -

-Refer to Section 7.4 of the RMP*eSubmit for the required PHA information. 
-The date of the most recent field verification that equipment is installed and maintained as designed
The most recent field verification of equipment was conducted September 2008 during a compliance audit. The field verification included the major equipment of the process. 
Pursuant to the requirements of California Health & Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Section 2745.6 (l) and 2745.7 (q), general events external to the plant that can conceivably cause a release were addressed by the PHA. 

7. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM The facility maintains an ERAP onsite that meets the requirements of the CCR Title 8 A?3220.  The facility has filed a Business Emergency Plan to help coordinate with local responders. 

8. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) study has been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility.  Planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the July 2006 PHA Report.
